column1: Some controversy exists over the source of the town's name. The city refers to the first county commissioners' meeting (1798)
column2: which named the town "Bolin Green" after the Bowling Green in New York City
column3: where patriots had pulled down a statue of King George III and used the lead to make bullets during the American Revolution. According to the Encyclopedia of Kentucky
column4: the name was derived from Bowling Green
column6: from where early migrants had come
column7: or the personal "ball alley game" of founder Robert Moore. Early records indicate that the city name was also spelled "Bowlingreen".

column2: Bowling Green had 154 residents. Growth in steamboat commerce and the proximity of the Barren River increased Bowling Green's prominence. Canal locks and dams on the Barren River made it much more navigable. In 1832
column3: the first portage railway connected the river to the location of the current county courthouse. Mules pulled freight and passengers to and from the city on the tracks.

column1: Despite rapid urbanization of the Bowling Green area in the 1830s
column2: agriculture remained an important part of local life. A visitor to Bowling Green noted the boasting of a tavern proprietor named Benjamin Vance:

column1: [Vance] says that he has seen a turnip this fall that measures thirty-two inches around
column2: and has a beet that weighs sixteen pounds and a half;... that corn in this country grows so fast that if you look at it the next
column3: it has grown a foot higher; that the "little hickory twigs" growing in the barrens have roots as large as his legs...

column2: the Louisville and Nashville Railroad (currently CSX Transportation) laid railroad through Bowling Green that connected the city with northern and southern markets.

column1: Bowling Green declared itself neutral in an attempt to escape the Civil War. Because of its prime location and resources
column3: both the Union and Confederacy sought control of the city. The majority of its residents rejected both the Confederacy and the Lincoln administration. On September 18
column5: around 1300 Confederate soldiers arrived from Tennessee to occupy the city
column6: placed under command of Kentucky native General Simon Bolivar Buckner. The city's pro-Union feelings surprised the Confederate occupiers. The Confederates fortified surrounding hills to secure possible military approaches to the valuable river and railroad assets. In November 1861
column7: the provisional Confederate government of Kentucky chose Bowling Green as its capital.On February 14
column9: after receiving reports that Fort Henry on the Tennessee River and Fort Donelson on the Cumberland River had both been captured by Union forces under Ulysses S. Grant
column10: the Confederates began to withdraw from Bowling Green. They destroyed bridges across the Barren River
column12: and other important buildings that could be used by the enemy. The city was subject to disruptions and raids throughout the remainder of the war. During the summer of 1864
column13: Union General Stephen G. Burbridge arrested 22 civilians in and around Bowling Green on a charge of treason. This incident and other harsh treatment by federal authorities led to bitterness toward the Union among Bowling Green residents and increased sympathies with the Confederacy.

column2: Bowling Green's business district grew considerably. Previously
column3: agriculture had dominated the city's economy. During the 1870s
column4: many of the historic business structures seen today were erected. One of the most important businesses in Bowling Green of this era was Carie Burnam Taylor's dress-making company. By 1906

column2: the city constructed its first waterworks system. The fourth county courthouse was completed in 1868. The first three were completed in 1798
column5: the first mule-drawn street cars appeared in the city. The first electric street cars began to replace them by 1895.

column1: Bowling Green's high income and job growth combined with a low cost of doing business led the city to be named to Forbes magazine's 2009 list of the "Best Small Places for Business". In an evaluation of 179 cities across the nation

column3: finishing ahead of Elizabethtown and Owensboro. The list ranked Bowling Green 34th nationwide for the lowest cost-of-living and 22nd for highest job growth.

column1: Russell Sims Aquatic Center – The largest "water playground" in south-central Kentucky. The center includes zero-depth entry into the water

Old Union School – Preschool through 12th grade Christian school
